title: From Berrettini upset to Fognini spat: Andy Murray breathes life into comeback in China
text:
Andy Murray has impressed during his three-week stay in China (Picture: TPN/Getty)

After a heated three hours and nine minutes tussle with Fabio Fognini ended in defeat, Andy Murray gave a six-word response to whether he could see any positives from a narrow loss to the world No. 12.

‘No,’ Murray muttered. ‘I’m very disappointed just now.’

That disappointment will surely wash away, perhaps it already has. Murray was, after all, speaking in the immediate aftermath of a highly fraught contest where he had told his Italian opponent to ‘shut up’ during an on-court row and failed to serve out the match twice before going down in a third set tiebreak.

Murray rowed with Fognini (Picture: TPN/Getty)

The fact he’s disappointed at all is testament to how far he’s come. Murray is no longer playing just for fun. Gone are the days where he’s just grateful to not be in agony. The serial winner is back.

Advertisement

This was just Murray’s ninth singles match at tour-level since undergoing a hip resurfacing operation in January, four of which he’s won. Two of the players who beat him – Alex de Minaur in Zhuhai and Dominic Thiem in Beijing – went on to win the title. Fognini still could, theoretically, do the same in Shanghai.

For a man who was in agony putting his socks on nine months ago, it’s easy to lose perspective on what he’s already achieved. Murray’s three-week stint in China has unquestionably been a roaring success.

So dramatic has his improvement been, both in terms of ball-striking and physicality, since the nondescript defeats in the American hard court summer, few would now bet against him returning to the upper echelons of the sport.

That belief was likely first instilled in many with a straight sets win over Italy’s Matteo Berrettini.

A US Open semi-finalist a matter of weeks before and, at the time, the eighth-best performing male player in 2019, it was a first-round match Murray was simply expected to lose. He won in two tight sets.

Andy Murray's results in China Zhuhai R1: 6-3 6-7 6-1 Sandgren

R2: 6-4 2-6 4-6 De Minuar Beijing R1: 7-6 7-6 Berrettini

R2: 7-6 6-7 6-1 Norrie

QF: 2-6 6-7 Thiem Shanghai R1: 2-6 6-2 6-3 Londero

R2: 6-7 6-2 6-7 Fognini

There have been times where he hasn’t played well. He looked on his last legs against compatriot Cameron Norrie a day after his battling win over Berrettini only to thump him 6-1 in a decider.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Against Juan Ignacio Londero, his forehand went AWOL in the first set only to make the necessary adjustments and win in three.

The fight has always been there. Indeed, in the first nine matches of his initial return from the hip injury in the summer of 2018, Murray actually racked up more wins (5) than he has now.

Andy Murray was disappointed after his loss to Fabio Fognini (Picture: TPN/Getty Images)

In the same year, there were wins over then top-20 players Kyle Edmund and David Goffin. Murray, despite often being in sheer agony, ended the season with seven wins to five losses. Even on one leg, his battling qualities alone are a force to be reckoned with.

These wins in China have been somewhat different. Murray is pain free. He’s not been left sobbing into his towel at the side of the court as he did after beating Marius Copil to reach the quarter-finals in Washington, lamenting the suffering he’d gone through to win. The fight remains but it’s more sustainable.

His movement is unrecognisable from the sorry hobbling athlete who was desperately clawing at former glories. Watching Murray has become an enjoyable experience again.

This HAS to be one of the points of the season!?! Incredible from @andy_murray 😱 🎥: @TennisTV #RolexShMasters pic.twitter.com/Iz0Z10pTG7 — ATP Tour (@atptour) October 8, 2019

Whether that be with surging darts to the net, the incessant chuntering at himself and his team, the stunning backhand passes, the sarcastic self-congratulation, the yowls as he races to retrieve from an uncomfortable position, the cries of ‘Let’s Go!’ as he wins an important point. Murray is box office again for, almost, all the right reasons. Even though he probably shouldn’t have engaged with wind-up merchant Fognini, it was somewhat satisfying watching him tell the Italian to pipe down.

Advertisement

The exciting part is still to come. Murray is not here to make up the numbers. Gone are the days where he’s smiling about just being on court, it’s full steam ahead with a focus on being fully fit and ready to be a genuine force at the Australian Open next year.

Just to hammer it home one last time: this is the same man who tearfully considered retiring in Melbourne just nine months ago, who has undergone an operation from which no singles player has ever returned to elite tennis.

But that was the past. Murray’s efforts in China have seen us all look to the future. In Zhuhai he rated his level – which has since continued to improve – at world No. 60 or 70, so how soon will he return to the top-50 or, even, top-20? Will he be British No. 1 by the end of next year? Can he seriously add to his three Grand Slam titles?

All will be answered in due course but the wider landscape is a far cry from the disappointment Murray was feeling on Tuesday.

As he leaves China, he could be forgiven for thinking this is the start of something special. On the evidence of the past three weeks, it may just be.
